title: 109_hr5413
content: The Act aims to improve the codification of title 46, United States Code, by incorporating public comments and amendments made after the cutoff date specified in a previous bill. It specifically addresses personal injury to or death of seamen. The Act amends Section 30104 of title 46, United States Code, allowing injured seamen or their representatives to bring actions for personal injury or death under US laws. The venue for such actions at law will be in the judicial district where the employer resides. The Act amends Section 53701 of title 46, United States Code, by redesignating paragraphs and defining terms like Administrator and Secretary. It also amends Section 53706(c) to prioritize certain vessels for guarantees under the Maritime Security Act of 2003. The Maritime Security Act of 2003 (46 U.S.C. 53101 note) allows vessels suitable for naval auxiliary service in times of war or national emergency to be eligible for guarantees. The Secretary of Defense must make a determination within 30 days of a request from the Administrator. Section 53707 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to include the Administrator in various subsections. Section 53708 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to replace references to the Secretary with the Administrator and to make adjustments in subsections regarding financial structures and risk factors. Section 53712(b) of title 46, United States Code, is amended to include requirements for additional payments, collateral, or equity contributions in the loan agreement if the Secretary or Administrator waives a requirement under section 53707(d). The amendments to title 46, United States Code, involve changes such as removing references to the Secretary of Commerce, inserting "of Defense" after "Secretary" in a specific section, and replacing instances of "Secretary" with "Administrator" in various sections. The amendments to title 46, United States Code involve inserting "Administrator" after "Secretary" in various sections, except when "Secretary" is followed by "of Transportation" or "of the Treasury". SEC. 4. MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS. Title 46, United States Code, is amended to change "Naval Reserve" to "Navy Reserve" in chapters 513 and 515. Section 51504(f) is amended to specify fuel cost payments to State maritime academies. Maximum payment amounts are set for fiscal years 2006-2008 and beyond. Section 51505(b)(2)(B) is amended to increase payment limits for fiscal years 2006-2008 and beyond. Section 51701(a) is also amended. Section 51701(a) is amended to include functions to assist the United States merchant marine as determined necessary by the Secretary. Section 51907 is amended to allow the Secretary of Transportation to provide decorations, medals, and replacements as authorized by the chapter. The new chapter 541, titled "Assistance for small shipyards and maritime communities," is inserted after chapter 539. Section 3506 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2006 is transferred and redesignated as section 54101 of title 46, United States Code. The heading of section 54101 is amended to reflect its new title. Section 54101(b) is amended by inserting "or" after paragraph (2), striking paragraph (3), and redesignating paragraph (4) as paragraph (3). Section 60301 is amended to adjust tonnage fees for fiscal years 2006 through 2010 and thereafter. The tonnage fees will not exceed 67.5 cents per ton per year for fiscal years 2006 through 2010, and 30 cents per ton per year for each fiscal year after that. SEC. 5. REPEALS. The following provisions are repealed, except for rights, duties, penalties, or proceedings that existed before the enactment of this Act. The Statutes at Large list various public laws and sections, including those from 1936 and 2006. The Statutes at Large list public laws and sections from 1936 to 2006, including sections 3502, 3547, 3507, 3555, 3557, 1271-1280, 1280b, 3509, 1295e, 3510, and 2004. On Feb. 8, sections 4001, 27, 121, and 132 are also mentioned. The Act will only take effect if H.R. 1442 in the 109th Congress is passed, becoming effective immediately upon enactment of the bill.
